case_name: Messrs. Ram Chand Sons Sugar Mills Private Limited v. Kanhaya Lal Bhargava

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 166 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 166 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the order

facts.text: Appeal by special leave against order dated August 27, 1965 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Civil Revision No. 289-D of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated August 27, 1965 of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi in Civil Revision No. 289-D of 1965.

facts.text: Kanhaya Lal Bhargava, the 1st respondent, filed a suit on April 27, 1962, against Messrs. Ram Chand Sons Sugar Mills Private Limited (appellant) and Ram Sarup for Rs. 45,112.94 in Court of Subordinate Judge, First Class, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: Kanhaya Lal Bhargava, the 1st respondent, filed a suit on April 27, 1962, in the Court of the Subordinate Judge, First Class, Delhi, against Messrs. Ram Chand Sons Sugar Mills Private Limited, the appellant,

facts.text: On October 27, 1964, 1st respondent filed application under O.XI r.21 read with O.XXIX r.3 for striking off defence or directing Jugal Kishore to appear on December 14, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the suit, on October 27, 1964, the 1st respondent filed an application in the said companyrt under O.XI, r. 21, of the Code, read with XXIX, r. 3, thereof, for striking off the defence or

facts.text: On December 3, 1964, court ordered Jugal Kishore, director of appellant-company, to appear on December 14, 1964, to answer material questions.

anchor.surface_text: On December 3, 1964, the companyrt made an order therein directing the said Jugal Kishore to be present in companyrt on December 14, 1964, to answer material questions relating to the suit.

facts.text: Appellant took multiple adjournments to produce Jugal Kishore on ground of illness.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took a number of adjournments to produce the said Jugal Kishore on the ground that the latter was ill.

facts.text: On February 3, 1965, court gave appellant final opportunity to produce Jugal Kishore.

anchor.surface_text: On February 3, 1965, the companyrt gave the appellant a final opportunity to produce the said Jugal Kishore.

facts.text: Appellant took two more adjournments but did not produce Jugal Kishore on ground of illness.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, the appellant took two more adjournments to produce him, but did number do so on the ground that he was ill.

facts.text: On February 25, 1965, court issued notice to appellant to show cause why defence should not be struck off.

anchor.surface_text: Finally on February 25, 1965, the companyrt issued a numberice to the 1st defendant, appellant herein, to show cause why his defence should number be struck off.

facts.text: On March 16, 1965, Subordinate Judge struck off defence of appellant holding Jugal Kishore failed to comply persistently.

anchor.surface_text: On March 16, 1965, after hearing the arguments the companyrt held that Jugal Kishore had failed to companyply with the orders of the companyrt and was persistent in his default in spite of chances given to him

facts.text: Punjab High Court confirmed Subordinate Judge's order striking off defence.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on revision, held that Jugal Kishore did number appear in companyrt in spite of orders to that effect and that the learned Subordinate Judge had Jurisdiction to strike out the defence

anchor.surface_text: Order XXIX. r. 1. In suits by or against a corporation, any pleading may be signed and verified on behalf of the corporation by the secretary or by any director or other principal officer of the corporation who is able to depose to the facts of the case. r.2 Subject to any statutory provision regulating service of process, where the suit is against a corporation, the summons may be served-- a  on the secretary, or on any director, or other principal officer of the corporation, or b  r. 3. The Court may, at any stage of the suit, require the personal appearance of the secretary or of any director, or other principal officer of the corporation who may be able to answer material questions relating to the suit.

concepts.unlisted_description: Cannot conflict with or override express Code provisions

issues.text: Whether Section 151 CPC can be invoked to strike out the defence of a party in circumstances other than those specified in the express provisions of the Code providing power to strike out defence

anchor.surface_text: The argument of Mr. S, N. Andley, learned counsel for the appellant, may be briefly stated thus The Code of Civil Procedure provides express power for a court to strike out defence against a party under specified circumstances and, therefore, s. 151 thereof cannot be invoked to strike out the defence in other circumstances, for to do so will be to override the provisions of the Code.

issues.text: Whether Order XXIX Rule 3 CPC empowers the court to require the personal appearance only of the director who signed and verified the pleading under Rule 1 or any director able to answer material questions

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the learned counsel for the appellant is that the director mentioned in r. 3 is the director mentioned in r. 1 thereof. To put it in other words, the director who signs and verifies the pleadings can only be required to appear personally to answer material questions relating to the suit.

issues.text: Whether Order XXIX Rule 3 CPC provides for any penalty for non-appearance of the director and whether the court can exercise inherent powers under Section 151 CPC to make consequential orders for such default

anchor.surface_text: Even so, learned counsel for the appellant contended that XXIX, r. 3, of the Code did not provide for any penalty in case the director required to appear in court failed to do so. By drawing an analogy from other provisions where a particular default carried a definite penalty, it was argued that in the absence of any such provision it must be held that the Legislature intentionally had not provided for any penalty for the said default.

issues.text: Whether the court can strike off the defence of the company for the default of its director in appearing in court under Order XXIX Rule 3 CPC

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the court can, as it did in the present case, strike off the defence of the appellant for the default made by its director to appear in court.

issues.text: Whether the company was responsible or colluded with the director in his failure to appear in court thereby abusing the process of the court

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied, as the courts below were, that Jugal Kishore, the director of the appellant-company, purposely for one reason or other, defied the orders of the court on the pretext of illness and had certainly abused the process of the court. ... Unless there is a finding of collusion between the appellant and the director in that the former prevented the latter from appearing in court, we find it difficult to make the company constructively liable for the default of one of its directors.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that a companyany and the directors of the companyany are different legal personalities. The companyany derives its powers from the memorandum of association.

holdings.text: The inherent power of a court is in addition to and complementary to the powers expressly conferred under the Code. But that power will not be exercised if its exercise is inconsistent with, or comes into conflict with, any of the powers expressly or by necessary implication conferred by the other provisions of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the said decisions, the scope of the inherent power of a court under s. 151 of the Code may be defined thus The inherent power of a court is in addition to and complementary to the powers expressly conferred under the Code. But that power will not be exercised if its exercise is inconsistent with, or comes

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesised from Supreme Court precedents in Padam Sen, Manohar Lal Chopra, and Arjun Singh defining limits on inherent powers to avoid conflict with express Code provisions.

holdings.text: Any director in r. 3 need not be the same director who has signed and verified a pleading or on whom summons has been served. He can be any one of the directors who will be in a position to answer material questions relating to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the learned counsel for the appellant is that the director mentioned in r. 3 is the director mentioned in r. 1 thereof. To put it in other words, the director who signs and verifies the pleadings can only be required to appear personally to answer material questions relating to the suit. Though this contention appears to be plausible, it is not sound

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeated use of 'any director' in Order XXIX rules 1, 2, 3 indicates broad scope; limiting to signing director would defeat purpose of enabling answers to material questions.

holdings.text: In a case of default made by a director who failed to appear in court when he was so required under O.XXIX, r. 3, of the Code, the court can make a suitable consequential order under s. 151 of the Code as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the court.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in O.XXIX of the Code. which, expressly or by necessary implication, precludes the exercise of the inherent power of the court under S. 151 of the Code. We are, therefore, of the opinion that in a case of default made by a director who failed to appear in court when he was so required under O.XXIX, r. 3, of the Code, the court can make a suitable consequential order under s. 151 of the Code as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of specific penalty in O.XXIX r.3 does not preclude inherent powers under S.151, as no express or implied bar exists, unlike exhaustive provisions elsewhere.

holdings.text: Unless there is a finding of collusion between the appellant and the director in that the former prevented the latter from appearing in court, we find it difficult to make the company constructively liable for the default of one of its directors.

anchor.surface_text: but neither of the courts found that the appellant was responsible or instrumental for the director not attending the court. Unless there is a finding of collusion between the appellant and the director in that the former prevented the latter from appearing in court, we find it difficult to make the company constructively liable for the default of one of its directors.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate legal personality of company and directors requires specific finding of company responsibility or collusion to attribute director's default to company.

holdings.text: It cannot be disputed that a company and the directors of the company are different legal personalities.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be disputed that a company and the directors of the company are different legal personalities. The company derives its powers from the memorandum of association.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established principle of corporate law distinguishing company as juristic entity from its directors.

precedents.cited_proposition: Inherent powers under s. 151 CPC are in addition to and complementary to powers conferred by the Code but cannot be exercised if in conflict with express provisions of the Code or against legislative intentions
precedents.cited_holding: Munsif had no inherent power under s. 151 to appoint commissioner to seize account books

Rai Bahadur Rao Raja Seth Hiralal 1  consi- dered the question whether a companyrt had inherent power under s. 151 of the Code to issue a temporary injunction restraining a party from proceeding with a suit in another State. In that companytext, Raghubar Dayal, J., after quoting the passage cited above from his earlier judgment, interpreted the said observations thus These observations clearly mean that the inherent powers are number in any way companytrolled by the provisions of the Code as has been specifically stated in s. 151 itself. But those powers are number to be exercised when their exercise may be in companyflict with what had been expressly provided in the Code or against the intentions of the Legislature.

precedents.case_name: Manohar Lal Chopra v. Rai Bahadur Rao Raja Seth Hiralal
precedents.cited_proposition: Inherent powers under s. 151 are not controlled by Code provisions but cannot be exercised in conflict with express legislative provisions as they dictate interests of justice

precedents.citation: Arjun Singh v. Mohindra Kumar 1964 5 S.C.R. 946, 968

anchor.surface_text: This Court again in Arjun Singh v. Mohindra Kumar 2  companysi- dered the scope of s. 151 of the Code. One of the questions raised was whether an order made by a companyrt under a situation to which O. IX, r. 7, of the Code did number apply, companyld be treated as one made under s. 151 of the Code. Rajagopala Ayyangar, J., made the following observations It is companymon ground that the inherent power of the Court cannot override the express provisions of the law. in other words, if there are specific provisions of the Code dealing with a particular topic and they expressly or by necessary implication exhaust the scope of the powers of the Court or the jurisdiction that may be exercised in relation to a matter the inherent power of the Court cannot be invoked in order to cut across the powers companyferred by the Code. The prohibition companytained in the Code need number be expressed but may be implied or be implicit from the very nature of the provisions that it makes for companyering the companytingencies to which it relates.

precedents.cited_proposition: Inherent power under s. 151 cannot override express provisions of the Code or cut across specific provisions that exhaustively cover a topic, even if prohibition is implied

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the said decisions, the scope of the inherent power of a court under s. 151 of the Code may be defined thus The inherent power of a court is in addition to and complementary to the powers expressly conferred under the Code. anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in O.XXIX of the Code. which, expressly or by necessary implication, precludes the exercise of the inherent power of the court under S. 151 of the Code. We are, therefore, of the opinion that in a case of default made by a director who failed to appear in court when he was so required under O.XXIX, r. 3, of the Code, the court can make a suitable consequential order under s. 151 of the Code as may be necessary for the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the court.
